Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interactions between knot homology and rep
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal details a comprehensive program which uses diagrammatic methods in categorified representation theory to obtain new results in representation theory and low-dimensional topology. One research objective seeks to exploit an analogy between knot homology and categorified representation theory to produce new representation theoretic objects arising from odd Khovanov homology. Another research direction seeks to use the powerful tool of categorical skew Howe duality to solve open problems in link homology theory for the special linear Lie algebra. This work will have applications to Landau-Ginzburg models in theoretical physics via the Kapustin-Li formula. The same diagrammatics used to encode the structure of categorified quantum groups will be used to transform current research into unique educational opportunities including an undergraduate research program at USC and innovative curriculum development of an undergraduate course on 'Diagrammatic Algebra'. The PI will also tap into the existing infrastructure of USC's community involvement to recruit high school students for a mathematics based event using diagrammatic algebra as a tool for engaging high school students.

An emerging mathematical philosophy known as "categorification" has significantly altered our perception of mathematics and the way we analyze our surroundings. Imagine if an architect studied a building by only examining its shadow. In much the same way, the perspective of categorification uncovers a hidden layer in mathematical objects allowing mathematicians to see the entire structure rather than its shadow. The PI's research uncovers these hidden structures in an area of mathematics known as representation theory which is closely connected to some of the most sophisticated models in theoretical physics. Following the philosophy that fundamental structures in mathematics should be simple and intuitive the PI utilizes a diagrammatic framework to encode a great deal of complexity into an intuitive diagrammatic language that greatly simplifies computations. The PI will incorporate this diagrammatic philosophy into transformative educational programs aimed at high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students making the tools of modern research accessible to a new generation of researchers. This award is co-funded by the Algebra and Number Theory program and the Topology and Geometric Analysis program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project employed the mathematical technique of categorification to uncover new structures and obtain new results in the fields of representation theory, low-dimensional topology, and theoretical physics.  This project resulted in the production of over 20 research articles by the PI, his post-docs, and graduate students.   During this projects performance period the PI supervised 5 post-docs and 6 graduate students who participated on this project. 

The scientific achievements obtained under the guises of this award include several developments in the field of higher representation theory.  New techniques coming from so-called trace decategorification have revealed new connections and unified a number of ideas.  We have explored fundamental dualities (Howe duality) and their implications for low-dimensional topology uncovering a rich interplay between symmetries and topological invariants. Further, this project supplied unique educational opportunities exposing students to cutting edge research activities. 

Specific educational activities performed under this grant include:

Diagrammatic mathematics for high school students: To illustrate the scope with which mathematics can be used, the PI worked with USC students to introduce High students from Augustus Hawkins High School to the subject knot theory. Using NSF CAREER resources, we brought students to USC for a day of mathematics related events. Together with a post doc at USC, we designed a "Knot Matching Game", where students were given various knots and asked to match them with a knot table of all distinct knots. Along the way students were exposed to a new type of deductive reasoning as they had to develop primitive knot theoretic tools in order to sort and classify the knots. USC Dornsife wrote an article about this event that contains additional details: http://dornsife.usc.edu/news/stories/1747/knot-a-problem.

Women in Math Symposium:  Building off the PI's involvement as a plenary speaker for the Young women in topology conference in Bonn, Germany from 2013, the PI mentored his two female graduate students, Ilknur Egilmez and Nicolle Sandoval Gonzalez, to help them organize a symposium for women in mathematics in the southern California area on February 11th 2017. The principle aim of this symposium is to create a network of women mathematicians in the Southern California area in order to nurture collaborations and provide a framework for mentoring.

Math Festival:  The PI mentored his graduate student Can Ozan Oguz to organize the third annual Mathematics Festival at USC on April 12th 2017. The purpose of this outreach event was to promote mathematicas within the university and the neighboring community. Our aim was to provide insights into what mathematicians actually do as part of their research. In addition to the USC and neighboring community, we also had 45 high school students participate from South Gate High School and Lennox Mathematics, Science & Technology Academy.

Two Volumes on Categorification: Together with Anna Beliakova, I have edited a two volume collection of research articles to be published by the AMS Contemporary Mathematics Collection. Our goal is to put together a collection of perspectives on categorification from the experts who have advanced this field.

YouTube educational videos: With the help of Dornsife productions, I helped produce an introductory video about knot theory designed to give the broad population a new perspective towards modern mathematics.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kxaWqKM5JyQ
